author: Mark Jefferies
title: England legend Alan Shearer to undergo dementia risk test after years of heading the football
text:
TV England legend Alan Shearer to undergo dementia risk test after years of heading the football In Dementia – Football’s Silent Shame former England and Newcastle United striker Shearer investigates the latest scientific research from Britain and around the world Share Alan Shearer will undergo tests to determine if he's at risk from dementia (Photo: BBC TWO) Share Get celebs   Thank you for subscribing!   
Footballer Alan Shearer is to undergo medical tests to find out if he could be at risk of dementia from heading the ball – as part of a new BBC documentary on the subject. 
In Dementia – Football’s Silent Shame former England and Newcastle United striker Shearer investigates the latest scientific research from Britain and around the world, including studies into Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE), a condition formerly believed to exist primarily among boxers. 
Well known for scoring headed goals himself, Shearer said he was concerned by recent reports and also having watched previous footballing ‘greats’ succumb to the ravages of dementia. 
Alan, 46, said: “After seeing the movie Concussion, I was intrigued. I was aware of former football players, legends who I grew up watching, suffering from dementia. 
"Could this affect football and footballers too? The more I read about it, the more I felt this was a subject that could no longer be ignored.” Read More Alan Shearer has headed the ball for years (Photo: BBC) 
Alan will meet footballers and their families affected by dementia before turning himself over to science. 
He will undergo a variety of cutting edge medical tests, including bio marker blood tests and transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) to uncover what condition his body and brain is in. 
The science is not straightforward and there have been calls for more tests. 
Alan will seek out scientific opinion that casts doubt on a direct link between dementia and brain damage caused by heading the ball. Alan Shearer will take part in the BBC documentary (Photo: BBC) 
He will also challenge football’s governing bodies on this potentially growing problem that is causing outrage in footballing communities as an issue that’s been ignored and neglected for years. 
The one off documentary was one of a host of new factual programming announced by the BBC on Thursday. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
